item.title: Xi Plays Long Game on US-China Trade as Trump Seeks Quick Wins
item.description: While Donald Trump hailed the outcome of trade talks in London, Xi Jinping walked away with an understated strategic gain: a negotiating process that buys China time and helps defuse the threat of more harmful tariffs and technology curbs.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping

item.title: Wealthy Australians Brace for a New Tax on Retirement Savings
item.description: Australia is forging ahead with a new tax on its richest retirement savers amid concerns that the country’s A$4.1 trillion ($2.7 trillion) pensions system is becoming a high-wealth accumulation vehicle.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson, Amy Bainbridge

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through Carlton Gardens in Melbourne, Australia, on Friday, April 5, 2024. Australians have become some of the world’s wealthiest retirement savers in large part because the law that created the super funds also established a steady source of funding.

item.title: China Forced to Keep Unprofitable Firms Alive to Save Jobs and Avoid Unrest
item.description: Saddled with the most loss-making industrial companies since 2001, Xi Jinping is trying to clean up his economy without triggering mass layoffs.

media:content.media:description: The Shaanxi Qinyang Changsheng Brewing Co. hasn’t turned a profit since 2020.

item.title: Argentina Inflation Hits Lowest Since Covid in Win for Milei
item.description: Argentina’s monthly inflation slowed to the lowest level since the height of the pandemic, scoring a major victory for President Javier Milei ahead of a crucial midterm vote.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

item.title: Key Senator Looks to Slow Ted Cruz Plan on Fed Interest to Banks
item.description: Senate Banking Committee Chairman Tim Scott said he opposes swift action on a proposal that would bar the Federal Reserve from paying interest on reserves to banks to help pay for Republicans’ massive tax and spending package.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Tim Scott, a Republican from South Carolina and ranking member of the Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee, speaks during a hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. Martin Gruenberg, the embattled head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. told lawmakers calling for his resignation that he was moving quickly to overhaul the agency's workplace culture after a probe detailed complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination at the agency.

item.title: IMF Sees Unwinding of Global Trade Surge Ahead of Trump Tariffs
item.description: The International Monetary Fund is seeing signs that the rise in trade and activity to front-run US President Donald Trump’s tariffs is beginning to unwind as the global economy still faces heightened uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi

media:content.media:description: Loaded container ships at Felixstowe port in Felixstowe, UK, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. The UK doesn’t plan to use a get-out clause to override her fiscal rules, even as the US tariff war roiled global markets, forcing down the pound and UK gilts.

item.title: South Africa Rail Firm Averts Strike as Unions Accept Pay Deal
item.description: South Africa’s state-owned ports and freight-rail company reached a pay deal with its two recognized labor unions, averting a strike that threatened to disrupt mineral and agricultural exports.
item.dc:creator: Katlego Mtshali, Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: A freight locomotive pulls wagons from the Transnet Pyramid South Depot in Gauteng, South Africa, on Friday, Nov. 17, 2023. Volumes of goods and commodities, including iron ore and coal shipped through the Transnet’s freight rail network for export, have dropped because of issues including vandalism, idle locomotives and cable theft. Photographer: Guillem Sartorio/Bloomberg

item.title: Canadian Support for Counter-Tariffs Dips as Trump Trade War Persists
item.description: Canadians continue to support retaliating against US President Donald Trump’s wave of tariffs, but their fervor has waned as the trade war wears on.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, right, and Dominic LeBlanc, Canada's minister responsible for Canada-US trade, during a news conference on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, June 6, 2025. Carney announced legislation on Friday to fast-track “nation-building” projects in Canada and remove internal barriers to trade in an effort to shore up the country’s economy from the US tariff barrage.

item.title: East Africa Plans Spending Boost to Offset Global Risk, Aid Cuts
item.description: East African finance chiefs increased planned spending to a record to sustain economic growth and mitigate the effects of geopolitical risks and cuts in foreign aid.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians in the financial district in Nairobi, Kenya, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Kenyan annual inflation remained below the 5% midpoint of the central bank’s target range for a 12th straight month strengthening the case for another interest-rate cut.

item.title: Bessent Sees Deficit Falling Over 10 Years After Tax-Cut Bill
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that there are a number of different assessments of the deficit impact of Republicans’ signature tax-cut bill, and that his own expectation is it will shrink borrowing over a decade.
item.dc:creator: Cam Kettles

media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent during a Senate Finance Committee hearing in Washington, DC, on June 12.

item.title: Trump Floats Higher Auto Tariff, Guts California Gas-Car Ban
item.description: President Donald Trump said he may raise US auto tariffs in order to boost domestic auto manufacturing, a move that could further ratchet up tensions with trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Keith Laing, Mario Parker

media:content.media:description: Vehicles waiting for shipment at a lot of a shipping terminal in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, July 25, 2024. Former President Donald Trump has reiterated an openness for Chinese automakers to build cars in the US as a way to boost the economy, signaling a potentially different approach from a Biden administration that has sought to keep out vehicles with links to the country.

item.title: Investor Anxiety Over ‘Revenge Tax’ Is Overblown, Barclays Says
item.description: A controversial provision in President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending bill aimed at penalizing countries with “unfair” tax regimes is unlikely to disrupt US bond and stock markets, according to Barclays Capital.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: US Household Net Worth Falls for First Time Since 2023
item.description: US household worth declined at the start of the year for the first time in since 2023 as Americans contended with a tariff-driven stock market selloff.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Realtors walk through a home during an open house in Seattle, Washington, US, on Tuesday, March 26, 2024. The National Association of Realtors agreed to settle litigation over commission rules for US real estate agents, clearing the way for possible changes in how Americans buy and sell homes. Photographer: David Ryder/Bloomberg

item.title: US Mortgage Rates Tick Down, Sending 30-Year Average to 6.84%
item.description: Mortgage rates in the US fell for a second straight week.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Epstein

media:content.media:description: Residential homes in Rodeo, California, US, on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2024. US mortgage rates declined last week to the lowest level since September 2022 in anticipation of Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts, stoking an influx of applications for home purchases and refinancing. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Trump’s Section 899 ‘Revenge’ Tax Worries Investors
item.description: A measure in President Donald Trump’s sweeping domestic policy legislation designed to penalize countries with tax policies the administration considers unfair is causing a stir on Wall Street.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin, Saim Saeed, Daniel Flatley, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: US Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent, US President Donald Trump and US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick. Photographer: Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images

item.title: UK Trade Secretary Reynolds Hopeful of US Deal on Car Tariffs Soon
item.description: UK Business and Trade Secretary Jonathan Reynolds said he was hopeful that a deal can be struck soon with the US to lower tariffs on British automobiles but indicated that negotiations over steel have further to go.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: New automobiles at the Port of Southampton in Southampton, UK.

item.title: Carney Sees Progress in Trade Talks Between US and Canada
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said he hopes to secure a commercial and security agreement soon with US President Donald Trump, though he tamped down expectations that a deal will be ready in time for the Group of Seven summit in a few days.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Spools of steel at an ArcelorMittal Dofasco facility in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Canada will keep its trade retaliation in place until the US lifts its own tariffs and commits to free trade, said Mark Carney, who will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s prime minister within days.

item.title: India, US Harden Stance in Trade Talks as July Deadline Looms
item.description: Trade officials from India and the US have hardened their stance on some key issues as they race to conclude an interim deal before higher US tariffs take effect in July, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A container ship docked at the Mundra Port of Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: US Recurring Jobless Claims Jump to Highest Since End of 2021
item.description: Recurring applications for US unemployment benefits rose to the highest since the end of 2021, adding to evidence that it is taking unemployed Americans longer to find a new job.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Job seekers attend a Diversity Career Group job fair in Los Angeles, California, US, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Applications for US unemployment benefits fell to the lowest level in two months, consistent with a stable labor market.

item.title: Traders Resume Fully Pricing In Two Fed Rate Cuts This Year
item.description: Traders are once again fully pricing in expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates twice this year as reports on US producer prices and jobless claims support a rally in the bond market.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Stanton

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian passes the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 3, 2023. Signs of labor-market slackening in May despite a pickup in hiring are likely to keep the Federal Reserve on hold this month while policymakers mull a hike later in the summer.

item.title: Muted US Producer Prices Add to String of Tame Inflation Reports
item.description: US producer price inflation remained muted in May across the board, another sign that tariffs have yet to result in higher prices for consumers and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Boesler

media:content.media:description: A worker uses a brushing machine to refinish reclaimed wooden siding at a sawmill in Pine Plains, New York.

item.title: ECB’s Schnabel Says Rate-Cut Campaign Is Coming to an End
item.description: The European Central Bank’s interest-rate cutting campaign may soon be over, with inflation and the economy both on track, Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel said.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

item.title: The ‘Canada Drip’ Helps Absorb Shock of US Tariffs
item.description: (Note to Supply Lines readers: Starting tomorrow, you’ll get our new Business of Food newsletter each Friday, a weekly look at how the world feeds itself in a changing economy and climate, from farming to supply chains to consumer trends, that replaces the Global Food Edition of Supply Lines.)
item.dc:creator: Ari Altstedter

media:content.media:description: A truck drives towards the Peace Bridge at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, April 2, 2025. US President Trump on April 2 plans to roll out tariffs on global trading partners, the centerpiece of his effort to bring back manufacturing to the US and reshape a world trade system he has long decried as unfair. Photographer: Laura Proctor/Bloomberg

item.title: China Can Play the ‘Small Yard, High Fence’ Game Too
item.description: I’m Malcolm Scott, international economics editor in Sydney. Today we’re looking at the role of rare earths in China’s negotiating strategy with the Trump administration. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott

item.title: Czech President Warns Country May ‘Stay Behind’ Without Euro
item.description: Czech President Petr Pavel called for the country to adopt the euro as a way to help trade and avoid being left out of key decisions made by members of the currency union.
item.dc:creator: Krystof Chamonikolas, Kriti Gupta

media:content.media:description: Petr Pavel, Czech Republic's president, in Prague, Czech Republic, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Pavel called on the US to give Europe more time and realistic goals to take care of the continent’s security and contain an increasingly aggressive Russia.

item.title: Serbia Unexpectedly Holds Rates as Caution Tops Growth Pace
item.description: Serbia’s central bank unexpectedly kept borrowing costs unchanged for a ninth month, sticking to a cautious policy approach even as inflation eases and economic growth slows.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: The Serbian Central Bank headquarters in Belgrade, Serbia, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. Serbia President Aleksandar Vucic attended events in Russia’s capital marking the 80th anniversary of victory in World War II and is expected to negotiate a new gas contract with Vladimir Putin. Photographer: Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Is in Good Position to Withstand Future Shocks, Lagarde Says
item.description: President Christine Lagarde reiterated that the European Central Bank is well placed to handle any abrupt shifts in the economy.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Fed Seeks to Preserve Labor Market Lessons in Rewriting Rates Strategy
item.description: The long period of low inflation before Covid taught the Federal Reserve not to fear low unemployment. But the shock of the pandemic reminded policymakers how painful high inflation could be.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: A worker assembles components on a diesel engine at an engine plant in Seymour, Indiana.

item.title: Bulgarians Are Getting the Euro, But Half of Them Don’t Want It
item.description: People are growing more concerned about the potential impact on prices.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: This picture taken on May 16, 2025 shows people listening the national antem of Bulgaria during a rally against the adoption of the Euro, organized by Vazrazhdane party in the national Palace of Culture in Sofia. Bulgaria is expected to get a green light from Brussels in June to adopt the common European currency, the Euro -- but the prospect is unsettling many citizens. Bulgaria has been trying for years to satisfy the European Central Bank's (ECB) conditions to join the euro zone, and hopes to adopt the common currency in 2026. The far-right has demanded a referendum on keeping the national lev currency, but its requests have been rejected by both parliament and the constitutional court. (Photo by Nikolay DOYCHINOV / AFP) (Photo by NIKOLAY DOYCHINOV/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: How Sparsely Populated Norway Amassed $1.8 Trillion
item.description: Of all the world’s sovereign wealth funds, Norway’s is one of the most unusual. These giant, state-linked investment vehicles tend to pick and choose what assets they hold to manage risk, maximize returns and further national strategic interests. Not so with Norges Bank Investment Management, which largely tracks global indexes in order to generate an income from the country’s oil and gas revenues.
item.dc:creator: Heidi Taksdal Skjeseth

media:content.media:description: An offshore oil drilling platform in the North Sea in Norway.
